metadata.name: Greek Mythology
metadata.description: Consolidated Greek mythology entries (Olympians, Titans, Primordials, Chthonic).

schema.label: Classification
schema.description: Classification such as Olympian, Titan, Primordial, Chthonic, etc.

values.Olympian: Major gods traditionally associated with Mount Olympus.
values.Titan: Pre-Olympian elder deities who ruled before the Olympians.
values.Primordial: Primordial forces or beings from the origin of the cosmos.
values.Chthonic: Deities or spirits associated with the underworld or earth.
values.Hero: Mortals or demigods famed for heroic deeds.
values.Other: Other classifications not covered by the above categories.

entries.godOf: Sky, thunder, king of the gods
entries.powers: Control of weather, thunderbolts, supreme authority
entries.physicalDescription: Mature, regal man with a beard, often holding a lightning bolt
entries.source: Hesiod's Theogony, Homeric Hymns, ancient art
entries.notes: Leader of the Olympians; son of Cronus and Rhea; overthrew the Titans; central father-figure with many offspring and myth variants.

entries.godOf: Marriage, women, queen of the gods
entries.powers: Protection of married women, divine authority
entries.physicalDescription: Majestic woman wearing a crown, often with a peacock
entries.notes: Sister and wife of Zeus; patron of marriage and familial order; appears in many myths as a jealous protector of marriages.

entries.powers: Control of oceans, creation of storms and earthquakes, shape-shifting
entries.physicalDescription: Powerful bearded man holding a trident
entries.notes: Brother of Zeus and Hades; associated strongly with horses and seismic activity; numerous local cults and epithets.

entries.powers: Strategic warfare, wisdom, patron of heroes and craftsmen
entries.physicalDescription: Armed warrior woman with helmet, shield, and spear, often with an owl
entries.notes: Born fully armed from Zeus's head in most traditions; patron of Athens and crafts; associated with civic wisdom rather than chaotic war.

entries.powers: Archery, prophecy, healing and disease, music
entries.physicalDescription: Youthful, beardless man often with a lyre or bow
entries.notes: Multi-domain deity; later classical sources often equate him with Helios (sun), though originally distinct; patron of prophecy (Delphi) and the arts.

entries.powers: Archery, protection of young women, control over wild animals
entries.physicalDescription: Young woman with bow and arrows, often with deer or hunting dogs
entries.notes: Twin sister of Apollo; virgin goddess associated with childbirth, wild spaces, and the moon (often linked with Selene).

entries.powers: Battle prowess, courage in combat, physical strength
entries.physicalDescription: Armed warrior with helmet, shield, and spear
entries.notes: Represents the brutal, chaotic side of war; often unpopular among gods and mortals; famously paired with Aphrodite in myth.

entries.powers: Inspiring love and desire, beauty, persuasion
entries.physicalDescription: Beautiful woman, often depicted nude or partially draped, with doves
entries.notes: Two major origin stories: Hesiod describes her as born from sea-foam after Uranus's castration; other traditions (Homeric) present her as daughter of Zeus and Dione.

entries.powers: Master craftsman, creation of divine weapons and artifacts
entries.physicalDescription: Bearded smith with hammer and tongs, sometimes depicted as lame
entries.notes: Divine smith; in some myths thrown from Olympus and crippled; associated with volcanoes and metalworking; husband or consort relationships vary by source.

entries.powers: Speed, eloquence, guide of souls to underworld
entries.physicalDescription: Young man with winged sandals and hat, carrying a caduceus
entries.notes: Son of Zeus and Maia; messenger and psychopomp; trickster and patron of boundaries, travelers, and commerce.

entries.powers: Control over crops and seasons, fertility of the earth
entries.physicalDescription: Mature woman often holding wheat sheaves or a torch
entries.source: Homeric Hymn to Demeter, Hesiod's Theogony
entries.notes: Mother of Persephone; her search for Persephone explains the seasons; central in the Eleusinian Mysteries.

entries.powers: Inducing ecstasy and madness, viticulture, theatrical arts
entries.physicalDescription: Youthful man crowned with ivy, often holding a thyrsus and wine cup
entries.notes: Often called 'twice-born' (son of Zeus and Semele); associated with ecstatic cults, theater, and the vine; origins and cult practices vary regionally.

entries.powers: Protection of hearth and family, domestic stability
entries.physicalDescription: Modest, veiled woman often depicted near the hearth
entries.notes: One of the original Twelve Olympians in some lists; often a peaceful, non-confrontational deity central to household cults.

entries.powers: Rule over the dead, invisibility (helm of darkness), mineral wealth
entries.physicalDescription: Dark-bearded man often with a scepter and Cerberus
entries.notes: Ruler of the underworld and husband of Persephone; sometimes counted among the Olympians but primarily a chthonic (underworld) deity with distinct cults and attributes.

entries.godOf: Spring, vegetation, queen of the underworld
entries.powers: Control over plant life cycle, queen of the dead
entries.physicalDescription: Young woman often shown with flowers and grain, sometimes with Hades
entries.notes: Daughter of Demeter; her abduction by Hades explains seasonal cycles; central to Eleusinian rites.

entries.powers: Liminal magic, protection of thresholds, guidance in the underworld
entries.physicalDescription: Often depicted holding torches, sometimes triple-formed
entries.notes: Liminal and chthonic goddess associated with magic and crossroads; later syncretized into various cults.

entries.powers: Conveying peaceful death, escorting souls
entries.physicalDescription: Somber winged youth or stern figure
entries.notes: Personification of death; brother of Hypnos; distinct from violent death personifications and from Hades.

entries.powers: Bringing sleep and dreams
entries.physicalDescription: Gentle, reclining figure often with wings
entries.notes: Brother of Thanatos; appears in Homeric epics and later poetic traditions.

entries.godOf: Retribution, vengeance for oaths and blood crimes
entries.powers: Pursuit of oath-breakers and murderers
entries.physicalDescription: Often winged, tormented figures with serpentine hair
entries.notes: Also called Furies; chthonic agents of moral retribution with strong cultic presence.

entries.godOf: River of the underworld, sacred oaths
entries.powers: Binding oaths, guardian of the underworld's river
entries.physicalDescription: Personified river goddess
entries.notes: River-nymph and goddess; riverside oaths sworn by the gods invoked Styx's name.

entries.powers: Generation of life, earth-shaping
entries.physicalDescription: Personified earth, often maternal
entries.notes: Primordial mother goddess; birthed the Titans and many creatures; central in cosmogony myths.

entries.powers: Sky personification, progenitor of Titans
entries.physicalDescription: Personified sky
entries.notes: Consort of Gaia; father of the Titans; overthrown by his son Cronus.

entries.powers: Control over night and shadowy forces
entries.physicalDescription: Dark-robed figure of the night
entries.notes: Powerful primordial deity; mother of many personifications (Hypnos, Thanatos, etc.); worshiped in mysterious, often chthonic rites.

entries.powers: Primordial emptiness from which order and gods emerge
entries.physicalDescription: Often conceptual rather than anthropomorphic
entries.notes: The original gap or void in Hesiod's cosmogony; parent of some early forces in the cosmos.

entries.godOf: The abyss, prison of the defeated gods and Titans
entries.powers: Abyssal imprisonment and primordial chthonic force
entries.physicalDescription: Personified underworld abyss
entries.notes: Both a place and a primordial power; used as the deepest part of the underworld and a prison for enemies of the gods.

entries.powers: Personified darkness and shadowy regions
entries.physicalDescription: Shadowy, dark figure
entries.notes: Primordial embodiment of darkness, often paired with Nyx; parent of several chthonic personifications.

entries.powers: Personification of the pure upper air breathed by the gods
entries.physicalDescription: Bright, luminous presence
entries.notes: Represents the bright, upper atmosphere and is parent to other celestial personifications.

entries.powers: Bringing daylight and daily cycle
entries.physicalDescription: Personified day, radiant female figure
entries.notes: Daughter of Erebus and Nyx in some accounts; alternates with Nyx in cosmogonic roles.

entries.powers: Primordial creative force of attraction in some traditions
entries.physicalDescription: From primordial force to youthful god in later myths
entries.notes: In Hesiod Eros is a primordial force; later literature portrays him as a playful love-god (son of Aphrodite).

entries.godOf: Time (later associations), ruler of the Titans
entries.powers: Rule over the Titan generation, agricultural associations in some cults
entries.physicalDescription: Often an aged bearded figure or a scythe-bearing god
entries.notes: Leader of the Titans; father of Zeus, Poseidon, Hades; overthrown by his children in the Titanomachy.

entries.powers: Mother of the Olympians, protective maternal powers
entries.physicalDescription: Mature motherly figure
entries.notes: Wife of Cronus and mother of the first-generation Olympians; hid Zeus to save him from Cronus.

entries.powers: Cunning intelligence, fire-bringer to humans
entries.physicalDescription: Often shown as a clever, younger titan figure
entries.notes: Stole fire for humans and suffered for it; culture-hero figure with varied myths about his punishment and role.

entries.powers: Bearing heavy burdens (punished to hold the heavens), strength
entries.physicalDescription: Powerful figure often pictured holding the celestial sphere
entries.notes: Punished after the Titanomachy to hold up the sky; later mythic roles include encounters with Heracles.

entries.powers: Personification of the world-ocean, control over waters
entries.physicalDescription: Often depicted as a bearded man with aquatic features
entries.notes: Titanic personification of the great river encircling the world; husband of Tethys and father of river gods and Oceanids.

entries.powers: Oracular and intellectual associations in later tradition
entries.physicalDescription: Titanic elder, often shown as a stately man
entries.notes: Less prominent Titan; associated with the intellect and sometimes with the north.

entries.godOf: Constellations and the measure of the heavens (ancient associations)
entries.powers: Cosmic ordering in Hesiodic genealogy
entries.physicalDescription: Elder Titan figure
entries.notes: Obscure Titan with few myths; part of the original Titan generation.

entries.powers: Connections to heavenly light and the sun's ancestors
entries.physicalDescription: Radiant elder often associated with celestial bodies
entries.notes: Father of Helios, Selene, and Eos in some genealogies; sometimes conflated with solar figures.

entries.powers: Progenitor of important mortals and culture-heroes
entries.physicalDescription: Titanic patriarch
entries.notes: Father of Prometheus, Epimetheus, Atlas, and Menoetius; connected to human condition myths.

entries.powers: Illumination and precious metals/gems associations
entries.physicalDescription: Titaness often linked to brilliance
entries.notes: Mother of Helios, Selene, and Eos in some traditions; associated with sight and heavenly light.

entries.powers: Prophecy and maintaining cosmic order
entries.physicalDescription: Often depicted as a matronly figure with a scale or cornucopia
entries.notes: Goddess of justice and order; mother of the Horae (Seasons) and the Moirai (Fates) in some accounts.

entries.powers: Memory and the mother of the Muses
entries.physicalDescription: Titaness often portrayed as serene and recollective
entries.notes: Mother of the Nine Muses by Zeus; foundational to poetic tradition.

entries.powers: Oracular associations, lunar/bright aspects in some myths
entries.physicalDescription: Elder Titaness
entries.notes: Associated with prophetic power; grandmother of Apollo and Artemis in some genealogies.

entries.godOf: Fresh water, nursing of rivers and springs
entries.powers: Mothering of rivers (Potamoi) and Oceanids
entries.physicalDescription: Titaness often shown with water attributes
entries.notes: Wife of Oceanus and mother of many river gods and nymphs; important in freshwater cultic contexts.
